instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
Removed F7040.

when plug real charger, pin 1 slowly drop from 12.5v and then cycling.

When plug in fake charger, pin 1 dropped from 12.5v to 0.1v and stay there..

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground at pin 2/F7140.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: both pin 1 and pin 2 diode mode to ground is 377

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
you mean F7040 instead of F7140 right? 

If so, both pin 1 and pin 2 diode mode reading is 377 when the fuse is removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
Correct, is F7040.

With fuse in place, still cycling <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> appears at same time.
Check siode mode to ground on all big coils.
Also check if starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
Under normal situation, when the fuse is removed. pin 1 should have stable 12.5v right? [and it is not]

May I ask what is the rationale behind this to put the fuse back instead of looking troubleshooting pin 1? [really trying to learn]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: Some old models fluctuates if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not detected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
yes sir. with fuse in place, 12.5v is now stable [ i dont think it was stable before].

Fan starts and stop and cycling...

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> cycling between 3.3v and 0v.

How to do SMC bypass when the board is removed from the case?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
Solder an wire to a convenient point of <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> line.
Then touch any metal plate of the chassis (ground).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
SMC bypass mode: high speed fan, but still on and off

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is cycling between 1.1v and 0v [diode mode to ground is 063. Known good is 059]
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX</SIGNAL> is cycling between 0.86v and 0v [diode mode to ground is 139. Known good is 067]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: Both <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulse between 3.3v and 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable?

Just in case, try known good BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable at 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: GPU voltage tries to appear?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL> pulses between 3.3v and 0v.
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0GPU</SIGNAL> pulses between 1.05v and 0v.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> pulses between 0.4v and 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
Check if all output voltages from page 72 try to appear.

Also check if board stays on removing <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
page 72:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>  = 3.5v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL>  = 1.61v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.18v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_GPUIFPX</SIGNAL> = 1.73v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL> = 3.24v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5v pusling


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL>  seem to be slightly higher.. is that OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
Not big difference.
What about <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR> removing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
same thing if <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR> is removed. fan spin on and off.

already tried known good bios too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: Still turns off if remove RAM modules?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message: do I put <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR> back now for testing this ram remove?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light cycling at pin1 of F7040 with real charger but stay at 0.1v with fake charger
threads.message:
You can test without <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR>.
Resolder it is OK, if no change once removed.
